Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility due to health under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether Rashid is inadmissible under s. 38(1) of IRPA due to excessive demand on health services
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 38(1)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Rashid is HIV-positive, asymptomatic, submitted financial support documents and medical reports; medication costs exceeded health cost threshold
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Federal Court dismissed the application, upheld the visa officer's decision as reasonable
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Visa officer assessed medical condition and costs, determined excessive demand
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Excessive demand on health services due to high medication costs
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Projected cost of medication exceeding provincial health cost threshold
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Procedural fairness in visa officer’s assessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not applicable – no credibility challenge raised
Crimes.Application_Basis: Potential excessive demand on publicly funded health services
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Individuals whose health conditions may cause excessive demand on health services are inadmissible under IRPA
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Potential burden on public health system outweighs private financial support
Crimes.Cause_Description: Rashid's HIV-positive status and high medication costs led to inadmissibility determination
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Medical and financial evidence properly considered by visa officer
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Visa officer relied on medical officer’s assessment and cost data
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Cost of treatment exceeds threshold; financial support does not eliminate public health system risk
Crimes.Decision_Making_Body: Visa Officer, supported by Medical Officer

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on health costs

Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), s. 38(1)(c)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evaluation of medication cost projections and financial support claims
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate no excessive demand
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Rashid’s ability to pay privately questioned in context of public system impact

Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Duty of visa officer to consider private payment options
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: High cost of HIV medication exceeding health cost threshold
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Visa Officer with input from Medical Officer
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Process found fair; officer considered relevant factors
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and associated regulations on health-related inadmissibility
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Argued that private funding should negate excessive demand
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Maintained that public system costs remain at risk regardless of private payment
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certified question on duty to assess private payment
